claim.text: Americans check their phones an average of 96 times per day (Asurion, 2019)
claim.claim: Asurion published a study in 2019 finding Americans check their phones an average of 96 times per day

results.summary: Asurion did publish a study in November 2019 finding Americans check their phones an average of 96 times per day.
results.detail: The claim accurately cites the Asurion 2019 study, which reported that Americans check their phones 96 times per day on average (up from 80 times in their 2017 study). This was widely covered in media outlets at the time of release. Note that the figure is based on self-reported survey data rather than device tracking.

claim.text: Concrete attenuates WiFi signal by 10–15 dB per wall
claim.claim: Concrete walls attenuate WiFi signal by 10–15 dB per wall

results.summary: The 10-15 dB attenuation figure for concrete walls is consistent with established RF engineering measurements and industry guidelines.
results.detail: Standard RF engineering references and WiFi deployment guides (from Cisco, NETGEAR, and academic sources) consistently cite concrete walls as causing approximately 10-15 dB of attenuation at 2.4 GHz frequencies, with higher attenuation at 5 GHz. The exact value depends on wall thickness, concrete density, and presence of rebar. Thinner concrete or concrete block may be on the lower end (10-12 dB), while thick reinforced concrete can exceed 15 dB. The claimed range of 10-15 dB per wall is a well-established engineering approximation.
sources: Unable to verify via live web search - assessment based on established RF engineering knowledge from Cisco wireless deployment guides, IEEE 802.11 propagation studies, and standard building material attenuation tables

claim.claim: Dense masonry attenuates WiFi signal by 8–12 dB

results.summary: The 8-12 dB attenuation range for dense masonry is consistent with established RF engineering literature and industry sources.
results.detail: Multiple RF engineering sources, including Cisco's wireless deployment guides and IEEE studies on building material penetration loss, document that brick and concrete masonry walls typically attenuate 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz WiFi signals by approximately 6-15 dB depending on thickness and density. The 8-12 dB range cited is well within the commonly reported values for single-layer dense masonry construction. Standard references include Cisco's 802.11 deployment documentation and various building material RF attenuation tables used in wireless network planning.

claim.text: A signal reduction of 20–25 dB — the range achieved by two masonry walls
claim.claim: Two masonry walls achieve WiFi signal reduction of 20–25 dB

results.summary: The claim that two masonry walls achieve 20-25 dB WiFi signal reduction aligns well with established RF attenuation measurements for masonry/concrete materials.
results.detail: Technical literature and wireless network planning guides typically cite single masonry or concrete walls as causing 10-15 dB of signal attenuation at 2.4 GHz frequencies, with higher attenuation at 5 GHz. Two such walls would cumulatively produce approximately 20-30 dB of attenuation, making the claimed 20-25 dB range reasonable and consistent with engineering standards. Cisco, iBwave, and other wireless infrastructure vendors publish similar figures in their deployment guides.
